title: In Ukraine, gamers make the best drone pilots
summary: Now more deadly than any other weapon, drones have changed the face of the fighting between Kyiv and Moscow. Pending a solution to the conflict, Ukraine is focusing on training and recruiting the people who make the best pilots: gamers.

title: Europe takes its time to respond to Trump's tariff offensive
summary: The European Commission still hopes to negotiate with Washington to mitigate the damage that the announced tariff increases would cause. The first wave of retaliations, initially set to take effect on April 1, have been postponed for some until mid-April and for others until mid-May.

title: Guitarist and singer Amadou Bagayoko dies at 70 following an illness
summary: Amadou formed half of the famous music duo Amadou & Mariam, the 'blind couple from Mali.' Their France-based manager Yannick Tardy, who had just spoken to Mariam by phone, said that Amadou was taken to a clinic after feeling fatigued, then died in the afternoon on Friday.

title: Trump extends TikTok deadline another 75 days as US continues to look for a deal
summary: US President Donald Trump on Friday extended the deadline for TikTok to find a non-Chinese buyer or face a ban in the United States, allowing 75 more days to find a solution.

title: US cardinal accused of historical misconduct, sex abuse dies at 94
summary: Theodore McCarrick, the former archbishop of Washington, was suspected of various sexual assaults against minors and young men. Pope Francis, under fire for a growing abuse scandal in the Catholic Church, expelled him from the priesthood in 2019.  A Vatican probe found he had assaulted a teenager five decades earlier.

title: Tariffs: In Savoie, the Dolin House fears for its vermouth sales in the United States
summary: The Chambéry distillery anticipates a 40% jump in the price of its aperitif for American consumers as 70% of its exports head across the Atlantic.

title: Trump and Vance support Marine Le Pen after her conviction
summary: US President Donald Trump called the conviction of French far-right leader Marine Le Pen for embezzlement a 'witch hunt,' while Vice President JD Vance said her ban on running for office was 'not democracy.'

title: China responds to Trump's tariffs with trade measures and a WTO lawsuit
summary: China responded to US President Donald Trump's new customs duties by measures such as imposing the same 34% tariff rate on bilateral trade, expanding export controls and filing a suit with the World Trade Organization.

title: In Taiwan, Mazu, goddess of the sea and Chinese influence
summary: Taiwanese authorities are convinced that the worship surrounding this popular deity is enabling Beijing to spread its ideas in favor of absorbing the island into the mainland.

title: Putin's delay tactics stall talks with US over Ukraine truce
summary: Despite Donald Trump's early concessions to Russia, peace talks have stalled, and the only progress – a deal to halt strikes on infrastructure – remains largely ineffective.

title: UK and France accuse Russian President Putin of delaying Ukraine ceasefire efforts
summary: As Russian forces prepare to launch a new military offensive in the coming weeks, a Kremlin envoy has indicated that outstanding issues are stalling ceasefire talks.

title: Acceleration of Le Pen's appeal undermines principle of equality before the law
summary: The decision to bring the date of far-right leader Marine Le Pen's appeal trial forward to 2026, so that it happens ahead of the 2027 presidential election, raises a series of questions that weaken the judiciary.

title: France urges 'patriotism' from firms after Macron call to suspend US investment
summary: 'It is clear that if a large French company agrees to open a factory in the United States, it would give the Americans a point,' Finance and Economy Minister Eric Lombard said.

title: Future House of African Worlds struggles to establish itself in Paris
summary: Just months before its opening in a temporary space in eastern Paris, the MansA, envisioned by President Emmanuel Macron, is still awaiting funding from the Ministry of Culture.

title: What does France export to the US?
summary: Certain French sectors are especially reliant on exports to the United States and risk being hit hard by the 20% tariffs announced by Donald Trump on Wednesday.

title: Figurative art back in force at Art Paris fair
summary: The 27th edition of the fair, held at the Grand Palais in Paris until April 6, has a large selection of galleries showing diverse artworks – with figurative art back in force.

title: Macron tries to unite French industries in the face of new US tariffs
summary: The French president criticized Donald Trump's abrupt imposition of tariffs and called on French businesses to suspend investments in the US while talks are ongoing.

title: British comedian and actor Russell Brand charged with rape and sexual assault
summary: Brand was charged with one count of rape, indecent assault and oral rape as well as two counts of sexual assault, said London's Metropolitan police on Friday.

title: Le Pen's 'Plan B' stood for Bardella – until it became likely
summary: The far-right Rassemblement National party is refusing to prepare Jordan Bardella for the 2027 presidential election, fearing it would weaken Marine Le Pen, who is hoping to overturn her ban on running in elections.

title: US stocks plunge, extending selloff on escalating trade war
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warned of the risk of higher unemployment and higher inflation due to tariff increases he characterized as 'significantly larger than expected.'

title: In Spain, teenagers are as free as the air
summary: 'Parenting elsewhere.' Twice a month, one of our journalists overseas explores parenting beyond our borders. Spanish parents have no problem letting their offspring stay out until the late hours of the evening. Is this hands-off parenting or based on trust?

title: Laura Loomer, the MAGA influencer behind the firing of the NSA director
summary: This thirty-something known for her racist and xenophobic remarks personally asked Donald Trump to dismiss General Haugh, appointed under Biden to head the American intelligence agency, and several other senior officials. Their mistakes? Supposed disloyalty to the American president.

title: Russian strike kills 18 in Zelensky's home city
summary: Russia's Ministry of Defense said on Friday it 'delivered a precision strike with a high-explosive missile at a restaurant' in the city 'where commanders of formations and Western instructors were meeting.'

title: The new Trump era: A time of impunity for white-collar crime
summary: In just a few weeks, the American president has pardoned several economic offenders, swindlers of investors and inveterate liars. These con artists often have in common that they were pursued or sentenced by judges who opposed Trump before his re-election.

title: In Paris, stuffed dough dishes go far beyond ravioli and dumplings: Here are Le Monde's five favorites
summary: Whether it's Georgian khinkali, Chinese guotie or Ukrainian varenyky, the French capital offers a world tour of various ingredients cooked in dough.

title: Wall Street plunges after China reacts to Trump's tariffs
summary: China's response to the tariffs announced by Donald Trump has intensified panic in the markets, which are unable to manage such a level of uncertainty.

title: 'French parents are the European champions of parental pessimism'
summary: Sociologist Romain Delès tells Le Monde about his research into parenthood and raising children in France. According to him, the French 'parental complaint' stems from structural gender inequality in the household and in French society.

title: Tariffs: A major global economic slowdown looms
summary: The US risks nearing stagflation, while Europe faces stagnation. American consumers could lose $3,800 in purchasing power, with the poorest being hit the hardest hit.

title: After Myanmar earthquake, citizens step in amid army's absence
summary: In Mandalay and Sagaing – two of the cities hardest hit by the earthquake that has claimed over 3,000 lives – local residents have organized their own relief efforts, supported by volunteers from Yangon.

title: Humanitarian workers in Gaza are powerless against Israel's 'war without limits'
summary: More than 1,200 Palestinians have been killed since Israeli bombings resumed on March 18. Israel has deprived the Palestinian territory of any aid for over a month. Supplies are running out, and the health system has been targeted.

title: US Congress in shock over Trump's trade war
summary: The US president's announcement on Wednesday to significantly increase tariffs shocked many lawmakers, including those in his own party. Some Republicans no longer hesitate to criticize the policy.

title: Nice, a new promenade for foodies
summary: Whether faithful to the 'cuisine nissarde' or more adventurous, modern gourmet restaurants are jolting the southern city. They are headed by chefs who have often worked in top establishments, such as Pierre Altobelli and Thomas Hubert.

title: Poor countries are victims of Trump's cynicism
summary: The tariffs announced by the US president on April 2 are set to impact the most vulnerable populations first and are threatening their countries' economies with collapse.

title: Trump tells Americans to 'hang tough,' trade war 'won't be easy'
summary: The US president defiantly doubled down on his tariff policy that took effect and promised that 'the end result will be historic.'

title: French restaurants experience rising failure rate amidst customer confidence crisis
summary: Insolvencies in this sector are at an all-time high. Fewer customers are coming in, driven away in particular by rising menu prices. Restaurant margins have shrunk.

title: PSG clinches another French football title, extending dominance over Ligue 1
summary: Thanks to their win (1 - 0) against Angers on Saturday at the Parc des Princes, Paris Saint-Germain ensured their 13th first-place finish in the French championship. This dominance affects the league's appeal.

title: Meet Michel Gaubert, the man behind fashion show soundtracks
summary: During the last Paris fashion week, he set the collections of six fashion houses to music. Since the 1990s, Michel Gaubert has been an indispensable presence on the catwalk scene. In his new autobiography, this Karl Lagerfeld devotee reflects on an exhilarating life spent at the crossroads of fashion and clubbing.

title: 'Tonton du Bled,' the journey of a French rap anthem
summary: This seminal track by the group 113, which humorously evokes the summer vacations of French people of North African descent, was an instant hit upon its release in 1999. Despite being withdrawn from airways and stores for years due to copyright issues, it has remained a classic.

title: Netanyahu expected to visit the White House on Monday
summary: President Donald Trump will meet with his Israeli counterpart on Monday for their second White House meeting since Trump's return to office. Tariffs, Gaza and Iran's nuclear program are expected to top the agenda.

title: Januar Land Rover suspends shipments to US in April over tariffs
summary: The UK luxury car manufacturer said it needed to address 'the new trading terms' created by Washington's tariffs.

title: Anti-Trump rallies draw thousands across the United States
summary: A loose coalition of dozens of left-leaning groups like MoveOn and Women's March organized 'Hands Off' events in more than 1,000 cities and in every congressional district on Saturday, the groups said. In Washington, organizers had predicted a turnout of 20,000 but by the afternoon, the number appeared considerably larger.

title: In Spain, tens of thousands march across the country to protest the growing housing crisis
summary: The housing crisis has hit particularly hard in Spain, where there is a strong tradition of home ownership and scant public housing for rent. Buying a home has become unaffordable for many, with market pressures and speculation driving up prices, especially in big cities and coastal areas.

title: UK governing party suspends MP Dan Norris after rape arrest
summary: The MP for North East Somerset and Hanham in South West England was elected to Parliament in 2024, defeating high-profile Conservative MP Jacob Rees-Mogg.  He was arrested on Friday, on suspicion of sexual offences against a girl and rape.
